lines.text: No one moves very far out of line. When you're young you think you're blazing a trail. One day you look down and notice it's a beaten track.
I could sell your heads to the Japs.
Can't have any king, save the one in London, sir.
I hope you know those are the largest boots in Asia sir.
If you were a communist how could you be king?
Only a communist would think of it.
Sir, what's the deal on the women? They free?
I have a special relationship with the spirits. I died once. I had to. I had to give up everything, even the will to live.
[first lines]
THE COAST OF BORNEO - April 1942 / Shortly after the fall of the Philippines the Japanese are triumphant in the Pacific
[first lines]

[coming ashore]
He's dead. He's dead.
Lights! It's a village.
No, no. That's Japanese.
There's no choice!
No, I've had enough. Bataan. Corregidor. You were wrong! We're free now. We're free. Free to go our own ways.
He had been hunting and caught nothing. Only me.
For them it is a man that counts. Not life.
Listen, you can no longer avoid history! I'm sorry. I've said that!
Shut up. History? The world's so full of crap, sooner or later, you're gonna step in it. You call that history?
What do you want.
Freedom, to be like we are.
Anything else?
Guns. So they can't take the freedom away.
Well, I'll see what I can do.
And grenades, mortars and mines, so they can't take the guns away.
History is written by unusual men. Some who even become kings, and some who make no more mark than that of a stone thrown into an ocean. What we have here... Well, we just don't know, do we?

The death agony of the Japanese army in Borneo was as sad as the sinking of a great ship. Bullets, explosives, poisoned arrows. Men stumbling through the night, mumbling incoherently. Hunger. Men eating weeds, leeches, insects - and each other. Despair, madness. For me, for us, the same period was as thrilling as a cavalry charge. May God forgive us.
From this day, from this time on, I'll never raise my hand against another man.
You feeling alright?
Did Judas feel aright?

Don't cry, little one. Don't cry. I'll be with you in the songs they sing in the longhouses. And then when you're older and you have children, well, you'll sing the songs to them. And then they'll sing to their children. And the songs, the songs will make you strong. And you won't need me anymore.
[last lines]
I'll always know that he's out there. A free man. I hope he found his valley, somewhere. Farewell, my king. Farewell.

[after the Japanese have sacked Learoyd's village]
Vengeance is futile. It never ends. You told me that. It's not man that counts, it's life, Learoyd. It's life!

[Brushing right past him]
Blood must be answered with blood.
I don't trust a man who can turn away from the hips and thighs fashioned by the spirits.
Do you trust me?
Yes... If I have a choice between the good or bad in the man, I choose to believe the good.
The 'warrior king'.
No, YOU're the warrior. I'm just king.
Who's Vivienne? You kept mentioning her name.
She's my fiancée.
So that's why you wouldn't... I said I never trusted a man who had no woman. I was beginning to worry about you.

[Narrating]
Borneo. For most of you, Borneo doesn't exist. An imaginary name on a map, like Tibet or Tierra del Fuego. The ends of the earth. But I know the island exists. You see, I was there near the end of the Second World War. My war. My youth. I was a botanist before. I've been a botanist ever since.

[narration continues]
That's why they chose me, I suppose. Special Operations trained me. I was to help lead the tribes against the Japanese. But I didn't lead them, really. No, that was someone else. I knew him. He was the last King of Borneo. It's all right to tell his tale now. The wind has swept away the stench of the corpses. And all that we remember is the flare of our youth.
